summary: This video explores the impact of penis size on male attractiveness, examining cultural, historical, and scientific perspectives.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen, followed by a scene featuring a man standing in front of a wall adorned with a striking mural. The mural depicts a woman pushing a shopping cart, with a large yellow banana prominently displayed. The text "DOES SIZE MATTER? HUMAN PENIS" appears at the top of the screen, while the bottom displays the logo of the Australian National University and the name "Professor Michael Jennions" from the ANU College of Medicine, Biology & Environment. The man, dressed in a light-colored shirt and khaki pants, gestures as he speaks. The scene transitions to include an image of another man, identified as "Brian Mautz," standing outdoors with a bird perched on his shoulder. The video then shifts to a split-screen image showcasing two magazine covers under the heading "Modern Western culture." The left cover, titled "Baggierights," features a group of people in a retro style, while the right cover, from Cosmopolitan, displays a woman with red hair and headlines about sex and beauty tips. The man continues to speak, gesturing towards the magazine covers, emphasizing the cultural context of the discussion. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man's commentary, the mural, and the magazine covers, highlighting the theme of size and its cultural significance.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing himself, mentioning his affiliation with the Australian National University, and stating he will discuss a study on the effect of penis size on male attractiveness. His tone is informative and academic. He notes the study was led by a former PhD student in his group, and that Western culture is obsessed with penis size. He says that you do not have to go far to discover this and notes articles asking "does size matter?" and whether larger penises are better, and mentions an obsession among men which implies penis size is highly advantageous. He then adds that there is a contradiction between emphasis on size and studies saying it does not matter, so he wonders what the truth is.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing in front of a white background, gesturing with his hands while speaking. He is dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants. The video begins with a comparison of two magazine covers, one titled "Baggier Nights" with a retro design and the other "Cosmopolitan" featuring a woman with red hair. The man appears to be discussing the differences between modern and past cultures, as indicated by the text "Many cultures, past & present" displayed at the top of the screen. He then points to a painting of a man in historical attire, followed by a photograph of a man in traditional clothing, and finally a statue of a nude male figure, emphasizing the diversity of cultural representations throughout history. The video transitions to a discussion of scientific literature on human sexuality, with the man pointing to two book covers: "Why Is Sex Fun?" by Jared Diamond and "The Mating Mind" by Geoffrey Miller. The text "Valid scientific questions" appears at the top, suggesting a focus on the scientific exploration of human sexual behavior. Throughout the video, the man's gestures and expressions convey his engagement with the topic, while the changing images and text provide a visual context for his discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by establishing the topic of penis size as a subject of interest across both modern society and historical cultures. He provides examples, mentioning cod pieces from medieval times and a penis gourd worn by a man from New Guinea. The speaker then transitions to the scientific angle, citing reputable scientists such as Jared Diamond and Geoffrey Miller, who have questioned the relatively large penis size in humans compared to other primates. The speaker's tone is academic and informative throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing in front of a screen displaying two book covers titled "Why Is Sex Fun?" by Jared Diamond and "The Mating Mind" by Geoffrey Miller, with the text "Valid scientific questions" above them. The man, dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants, gestures as he speaks, likely discussing the content of the books. The scene transitions to a new slide with the heading "Video animations," showing a photograph of a smiling man and a list of statistics related to male humanoid figures, including height, body shape, and penis size, with the calculation "7 x 7 x 7 = 343" and the note "95% of men in range." The man continues to speak and gesture, emphasizing the points on the slide. The background remains consistent throughout, with a plain, dark backdrop that keeps the focus on the presenter and the displayed information.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with one male speaker posing the question of a correlation between body size and penis size, then describes the rationale behind their research approach. He speaks with a formal, articulate tone, emphasizing a scientific perspective.  The speaker then shifts into a more neutral tone as he discusses the limitations of questionnaires and the need for objective methods. The clip concludes with a mention of finding an answer to the question.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands in front of a white background, presenting a slide titled "Video animations." The slide features a photograph of a smiling man with a beard and a blue shirt, alongside text that reads "343 male humanoid figures (i.e. bunch of naked guys)" and lists "7 height," "7 body shape," and "7 penis size," with the equation "(7 x 7 x 7 = 343)" below. The presenter gestures with his hands, pointing to the slide and emphasizing the information. The slide also states "95% of men in range," suggesting that the figures represent a statistical range of male characteristics. The presenter appears to be explaining the content of the slide, using hand gestures to highlight key points. The background remains plain and white throughout the video, keeping the focus on the presenter and the slide content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a study involving male humanoid figures, specifying variations in height, body shape, and penis size within a certain range. The speaker's tone is informational. Following this, the speaker continues by confirming that the range covers most men.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands in front of a presentation slide titled "Video animations." The slide features a photograph of a smiling man and text that reads "343 male humanoid figures (i.e., bunch of naked guys)" with bullet points listing "7 height," "7 body shape," and "7 penis size," followed by the equation "(7 x 7 x 7 = 343)" and the statement "95% of men in range." The presenter gestures towards the slide, pointing out the details. The scene transitions to a new slide titled "Extremes of Figures," displaying three grayscale humanoid figures of varying heights and body shapes against a black background. The presenter continues to gesture towards the figures, emphasizing their differences. The video maintains a consistent setting with a plain background, focusing on the presenter and the slides.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker emphasizing a point related to previous studies on body shape and height, mentioning "body shape is important," and that females prefer "V-shaped men" and taller men, setting this as a benchmark. He discusses how this information can be used to calibrate the importance of penis size. The speaker then transitions to discussing the extremes of the figures generated in the study, describing the features of the most pear-shaped, shortest figure with the smallest penis, and then the tallest, broadest-shouldered figure with the largest penis.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man stands in front of a black background, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. Behind him, three 3D models of human figures are displayed, each with varying body sizes and shapes. The text "Extremes of Figures" appears at the top of the screen, indicating the topic of discussion. The man continues to speak, and the text changes to "Penis size variation," with the figures now showing different sizes of penises. The text "5-13 cm flaccid" appears at the bottom, providing a measurement range for the flaccid penis size. The man uses hand gestures to emphasize his points, and the figures remain static throughout the video. The overall atmosphere is educational, with the man providing information on human anatomy and variations.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker who explains that figures were presented at "life size" to subjects. He mentions arranging them to move, demonstrating how this subtly increases the ability to perceive the penis size as the individual moves around. The speaker ends by saying, "okay".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands in front of a white background with the words "Data Collection" displayed at the top. He gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing the information being presented. A red banner appears on the screen with the text "Presented 53 fully lifesize video images to @ of 105 women," indicating the subject matter of the presentation. The man continues to speak and gesture, providing further details about the data collection process. The background remains plain and white, keeping the focus on the presenter and the information being conveyed. The video maintains a consistent visual style, with the presenter's gestures and the text on the screen serving as the primary elements of the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker describing a study. He notes that they "asked 105 women to view full life-sized video images." His tone is informative and academic. He further explains their reasoning for using life-size images, emphasizing the visceral response to size. He contrasts this method with "the more traditional approach of simply asking women to assess figures." A second, male speaker, with a more neutral tone says "Alright."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man stands in front of a white background, presenting information about a data collection study. He is dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants, and he gestures with his hands as he speaks. Behind him, a large screen displays text in red and white, detailing the study's methodology. The text reads: "Data Collection," "Presented 53 fully lifesize video images to @ of 105 women," "Ranked from 1 to 7 for 'attractiveness as sexual partners'," and "Mean of 3.1 seconds to respond to each video (i.e. fast)." The man appears to be explaining the study's findings, emphasizing the quick response time of participants. The setting is simple and professional, with the focus on the presenter and the information on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a study where women were asked to rank characters for attractiveness as sexual partners, and notes that women responded "very quickly", taking about three seconds per video. The speech is conversational and informative in tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man stands in front of a presentation slide titled "Data Collection." He is dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The slide behind him features three red text boxes with white lettering, detailing the methodology of a study. The first box states, "Presented 53 fully lifesize video images to @ of 105 women," indicating that 53 video images were shown to 105 women. The second box reads, "Ranked from 1 to 7 for 'attractiveness as sexual partners'," suggesting that the women ranked the images based on attractiveness. The third box notes, "Mean of 3.1 seconds to respond to each video (i.e. fast)," highlighting the quick response time of the participants. The background is a simple black and white color scheme, focusing attention on the presenter and the slide content. The man appears engaged and animated, using hand gestures to emphasize his points, while the slide provides a clear and concise summary of the data collection process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features one male speaker. He begins by giving an analogy, describing a scenario where someone is trying to buy a house and has three seconds to choose from a bunch of properties that vary in size, number of bedrooms, price, and distance from the city center. He uses an explanatory and informative tone, explaining how the decision made would reflect the relative importance placed on the different characteristics. He concludes by stating that this is effectively what they've done in the study.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man stands in front of a presentation slide titled "Data Collection." He is dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The slide behind him features four red text boxes with white lettering, detailing the methodology of a study. The first box states, "Presented 53 fully lifesize video images to @ of 105 women," indicating the sample size and the nature of the stimuli used. The second box reads, "Ranked from 1 to 7 for 'attractiveness as sexual partners'," explaining the criteria for evaluation. The third box notes, "Mean of 3.1 seconds to respond to each video (i.e. fast)," highlighting the quick response time of the participants. The final box mentions, "Standard evolutionary selection analysis," referring to the analytical approach used. The background is plain white, focusing attention on the presenter and the slide content. The man appears engaged and animated, using hand gestures to emphasize his points, while the slide remains static throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker with a neutral tone discussing an analysis, stating it's "uncontroversial" and used in studies of various animals. He mentions applying it to humans, and his background in biology, specifically working with crickets and fish. There are no discernible background sounds or music present.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands in front of a white background, presenting a slide titled "What traits matter?" with the subtitle "LINEAR SELECTION." He gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing the importance of body shape, height, and penis size in linear selection. The slide displays percentages for each trait, with body shape at 79.7%, height at 6.1%, and penis size at 5.1%. The man uses a pointer to highlight the text on the slide, engaging the audience with his presentation. The setting is simple and focused on the presenter and the slide, with no additional background details or distractions. The atmosphere is educational, with the presenter conveying information clearly and effectively.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing traits, noting linear or directional selection on body shape, and preference for a V-shaped male. He continues, mentioning height as a predictor of attractiveness, aligning with prior knowledge that "taller men are more attractive." Then, the speaker introduces penis size as also undergoing linear directional selection. He emphasizes the equal importance of height and penis size. The speaker concludes by restating this surprising finding and referencing their study.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man stands in front of a whiteboard, presenting information about linear selection and its impact on attractiveness. He is dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The whiteboard displays a list of traits and their respective percentages, with "BODY SHAPE" at 79.7%, "HEIGHT" at 6.1%, and "PENIS SIZE" at 5.1%. A red button with the text "HOW BIG IS BEST?" is also visible. The man then transitions to a graph titled "Most attractive penis size not in test range," which plots attractiveness against penis size in centimeters. The graph shows a dotted line indicating the average attractiveness level, with data points above and below this line. The man points to the graph, emphasizing the data points and the concept that the most attractive penis size falls outside the tested range. The background remains consistent throughout, with the whiteboard and graph being the focal points of the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker addressing a question about penis size, stating that the answer is unknown because the most attractive size was not in their test range. He explains that attractiveness increases with penis size but starts to plateau, not reaching a peak in their data. He concludes that the most attractive size is larger than that found in most men.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands to the right of a large screen displaying a graph. The graph, titled "Most attractive penis size not in test range," plots "Attractiveness" on the vertical axis against "Penis Size (CM)" on the horizontal axis, with data points indicating various sizes. A red banner across the graph reads, "Shorter time to rank males with small than large penis," suggesting a correlation between penis size and attractiveness. The man gestures towards the graph, pointing out specific data points and explaining the findings. The background is plain, focusing attention on the presenter and the graph. The man's facial expressions and hand movements indicate he is actively engaged in explaining the data, emphasizing certain points with his gestures. The video maintains a consistent focus on the presenter and the graph, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's position.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with one male speaker sharing an "interesting fact," mentioning that females ranked males with different penis sizes quickly, not consciously, but it "simply happened". He elaborates that females quickly dismissed a small penis as "unattractive" and moved on. There are no background sounds in the clip.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands in front of a colorful graph titled "Height vs penis size." The graph features a gradient of colors ranging from blue to red, with contour lines indicating different values. The man gestures towards the graph, pointing out specific areas and explaining the correlation between height and penis size. He uses his hands to emphasize his points, occasionally leaning towards the graph to highlight particular sections. The background is plain, focusing the viewer's attention on the man and the graph. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is engaged in a detailed discussion about the data presented.
events_list.audio_caption: An academic male voice starts the audio clip, providing a summary of how character interactions affect each other. He references an X-axis showing "height" of individuals, and a Y-axis showing "penis size". He continues to explain that this is like a contour map that joins values of "attractiveness". The color red is "high ground" and means "sexy." He then explains that a very tall individual with a very large penis is the most attractive. He also mentions that a short individual with a small penis is the least attractive and calls that individual "blue, unattractive". He continues to say that a short individual's attractiveness remains largely unchanged as "penis size" increases. For a tall individual, as penis size increases, they are going uphill and become more attractive. The speaker mentions in sum that penis size matters more for tall males than for short males. He concludes that the findings are similar regarding body size, or "body shape" (V-shaped or pear-shaped), showing similar relationships.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a gray shirt stands in front of a white background, presenting a series of conclusions from a study. He gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing the points on the screen. The first slide reads "Conclusions" with the subtitle "Some results support previous studies." The presenter then adds bullet points, stating "Taller men are more attractive" and "Broad shoulders/narrow hips are more attractive." As he continues, the slide updates to include "New Results," with bullet points "Diminishing returns on higher values" and "Traits interact to affect attractiveness." The man maintains a professional demeanor, using hand gestures to highlight key points. The background remains plain and white throughout, ensuring the focus stays on the presenter and the text. The video concludes with the presenter summarizing the findings, reinforcing the importance of the study's conclusions.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker summarizing research findings, emphasizing support for previous studies about attractiveness factors such as height and body shape. He discusses new results, including diminishing returns and trait interactions, and concludes by stating "penis size does matter, no matter what they say". The speaker presents the information in a matter-of-fact tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing in front of a presentation slide titled "Conclusions," which lists several points about attractiveness, including "Taller men are more attractive" and "Broad shoulders/narrow hips are more attractive." The slide also mentions "New Results," such as "Diminishing returns on higher values" and "Traits interact to affect attractiveness," with a highlighted point stating "Penis size does matter (no matter what they say)." The man, dressed in a casual gray shirt and khaki pants, gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing the points on the slide. The background is plain white, focusing attention on the presenter and the slide content. The video then transitions to a black and white logo of the Australian National University, featuring a shield with stars and waves, and the university's name alongside the Latin motto "NATURAM PRIMUM COGNOSCERE RERUM," which translates to "First to know the nature of things." The logo remains static, emphasizing the institution's identity. The video concludes with the logo still displayed, reinforcing the association with the Australian National University.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists of a single male speaker who expresses gratitude with the phrase "Thank you for listening," followed by a farewell "Goodbye." His tone is neutral and conversational. No other sounds are present.
